Different levels of scrutiny are applied by courts when reviewing government actions that classify people. When courts review governmental action that classifies people, they apply different levels of scrutiny based on the classification. The more suspect the classification, the higher the scrutiny level. There are three levels of scrutiny: strict scrutiny, intermediate scrutiny, and rational basis review. Strict scrutiny is the most demanding form of judicial review. Strict scrutiny is the most demanding form of judicial review, applied to governmental classifications that are constitutionally suspect or interfere with fundamental rights. Courts consider historical discrimination, minority status with unchangeable characteristics, or inadequate political protection to determine suspect classifications. When applying strict scrutiny to governmental action, courts consider if the classification is historically discriminated against, a minority group with unchangeable characteristics, or inadequately protected by the political process. Suspect classifications include those based on race, national origin, and alienage. The government must prove that its actions are narrowly tailored to a compelling government interest under strict scrutiny. When governmental action is reviewed, courts apply strict scrutiny to determine if it is narrowly tailored to a compelling government interest. The government must prove the constitutional validity of its action under strict scrutiny, showing that less discriminatory means are not available. Intermediate scrutiny, applied to "quasi-suspect" classifications like gender or illegitimacy, is less stringent than strict scrutiny but more rigorous than rational basis review. Intermediate scrutiny applies to "quasi-suspect" classifications like gender or illegitimacy, determining if the action is substantially related to an important government interest. The government bears the burden of proving constitutional validity under this scrutiny, which is less stringent than strict scrutiny but more rigorous than rational basis review. Rational basis review is the least searching form of judicial scrutiny, applying to classifications not subject to heightened levels of scrutiny. To survive, governmental action must be rationally related to a legitimate government interest. Courts consider the legitimacy of any possible governmental purpose behind the action, and it only needs to be a reasonable way of achieving a legitimate government purpose to pass rational basis review. Rational basis review is deferential to the government, as courts presume the constitutionality of governmental actions subject to this scrutiny.
